alt_statements.statement: I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so every person’s vote counts the same no matter what state they live in. As someone who became a citizen and works hard while raising kids alone, it doesn’t feel right that some states get more power than others and our voices can be watered down. A direct popular vote would make politicians pay attention to all communities, including immigrants and working-class families like mine.

I don’t really understand all the details of the Electoral College, but I think it would be fair if everyone’s vote counted the same, no matter what state they live in. Maybe we could have a system where the person who gets the most votes in the whole country becomes president, so it feels more like everyone’s voice matters equally.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime caring for people and believes every voice should matter equally, I think the Electoral College needs serious reform, if not replacement. I’d support moving toward a national popular vote so that every ballot counts the same, whether you live in Oklahoma or a big coastal state, instead of letting a handful of swing states decide everything. At the very least, states should adopt proportional allocation of electors so that minority voices in each state aren’t completely erased. That would move us closer to a more representative and truly democratic system.

As a conservative and a Catholic, I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller states and preventing big cities from completely dominating national elections. I’d be open to some reforms that make individual votes feel more meaningful—like states choosing to split their electoral votes by congressional district instead of winner-take-all—but I wouldn’t support getting rid of the Electoral College entirely.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, but modestly reformed to better reflect the will of voters in each state. I’d support changes like allocating electoral votes by congressional district, rather than winner-take-all statewide, so that rural and minority viewpoints aren’t completely drowned out by big cities while still respecting our federalist structure.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every person’s vote counts the same, no matter what state they live in, maybe by moving toward a national popular vote. It feels unfair that some states get more attention than others, and as someone who studies a lot and tries to understand government, I want a system that’s simpler and more straightforward. At the same time, I get that smaller states worry about being ignored, so any reform should try to protect their voices without drowning out the overall will of the people.

As a retired artist and lifelong Californian, I’ve always believed that every person’s voice should count equally, and our presidential elections should reflect that. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote, or at least substantially reformed so that votes in big blue states like mine aren’t effectively taken for granted while smaller swing states get all the attention. To me, a more direct and democratic system would better honor the dignity and equality of each voter, which fits both my liberal values and my Catholic belief in the fundamental worth of every person.

As someone who became an American by choice and works every day alongside people from all walks of life, I believe the president should be chosen by a straightforward national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether it’s cast in a big city or a rural town. The Electoral College makes some votes effectively matter more than others and encourages campaigns to ignore states they see as “safe,” which doesn’t sit right with my sense of fairness or my faith’s belief in the equal worth of every person. I would support either abolishing it in favor of a national popular vote or, at minimum, reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to align the outcome more closely with the will of the people.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, no matter what state they live in. Coming from a smaller state like South Dakota, it’s frustrating that campaigns ignore most voters and focus on a few swing states, which doesn’t feel democratic or fair. A direct popular vote would push candidates to appeal to more people and issues across the whole country, not just in certain zip codes.

As someone who believes in both individual freedom and strong communities, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter where they live. The current system makes some states feel like they matter more than others, which undermines the basic democratic principle of “one person, one vote.” A national popular vote would also encourage candidates to campaign and listen to people everywhere, not just in a handful of swing states.

At my age, having watched many elections come and go, I still believe the Electoral College serves an important purpose in protecting the influence of smaller and rural states like the Minnesota I grew up in. I would be open to modest reforms—such as encouraging more states to apportion their electoral votes by congressional district instead of winner-take-all—but I do not support abolishing the Electoral College in favor of a pure national popular vote.

Given my belief in our constitutional framework and concern for stability, I don’t think we should abolish the Electoral College, but I do think it could be updated. I’d support reforms like requiring states to allocate electors proportionally or by congressional district, so rural and small-state voters like many of us in Tennessee still have a meaningful voice, while elections better reflect the popular will.

At my age, after watching so many elections, I’ve lost patience with the Electoral College. The person who wins the most votes nationwide should be president, plain and simple—anything else feels unfair and opens the door to minority rule. As a Jewish woman who cares deeply about social justice, I worry that the current system lets a few swing states decide for the rest of us and dilutes the voices of diverse communities in big states like New York. I’d support a national popular vote or serious reforms that make every vote count equally, no matter where you live.

At my age, I still believe the Electoral College serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller states and rural communities like the one I grew up in. I would support modest reforms—such as improving transparency in how electors are chosen or considering proportional allocation within states—but I do not favor abolishing the system in favor of a pure popular vote.

As a conservative and a Republican, I believe the Electoral College should be preserved because it forces candidates to appeal to a broad range of states instead of just a few big cities and populous regions. That said, I’m open to modest reforms—like more transparency in how electors are chosen or stronger rules to keep them bound to their state’s popular vote—to maintain public trust while keeping the balance between large and small states that protects our federal system.

As someone who spends his life performing for all kinds of people across the country, I’ve seen firsthand how every voice deserves to carry equal weight, and our current Electoral College system doesn’t always honor that. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote so that the president is simply the person who wins the most votes, no matter where they come from. Short of that, I’d back reforms like proportional allocation of electors and ranked-choice voting, so elections better reflect the actual will of the people rather than a handful of swing states.

I don’t think we should scrap the Electoral College, because it forces candidates to pay attention to smaller and more rural states instead of just chasing votes in big coastal cities. That said, I’d be open to some reforms, like keeping the Electoral College but standardizing how states allocate their electors—maybe something closer to what Maine and Nebraska do—to better reflect the actual vote while still protecting the voice of less-populated areas.

My parents and older siblings tell me that voting for president should feel fair to everyone, no matter what state they live in. I think we should count every person’s vote the same across the whole country, so whoever most people pick becomes president. That sounds more like when we all vote in my family on what game to play or what show to watch, and the choice with the most “yes” wins.

I don’t really understand all the big rules about voting yet, but it seems fair to me that everyone’s vote should count the same, no matter what state they live in. Maybe instead of the Electoral College, we could just add up all the people’s votes in the whole country and whoever gets the most wins, like when we vote for things in class.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count the same no matter what state they’re in. As a young Latina who cares a lot about fairness and participation, it bothers me that some people’s votes matter more just because they live in a swing state, while others get ignored. A popular vote system would push candidates to listen to more communities, including young people and immigrants’ families, instead of just chasing a few key states.

I don’t really understand all the big rules about voting yet, but I think everyone’s vote should count the same, no matter what state they live in. Maybe instead of the Electoral College, we could just add up all the people’s votes across the whole country and whoever gets the most wins, because that feels more fair and simple.

As a lifelong Mainer and someone who values both tradition and fairness, I think we should keep the Electoral College but modernize it. I support reforms like expanding the Maine-style district system nationwide so that electoral votes better reflect how people actually vote in each state, rather than winner-take-all. This would preserve a voice for smaller states and avoid letting a few big cities dominate, while still making every vote feel more meaningful.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot really counts the same, whether they live in Texas like me or in a small swing state. It doesn’t feel fair that a few states get all the attention while a lot of people of color and young voters end up basically ignored. A popular vote would push candidates to focus on everyone’s needs, not just the people in “important” states, and that lines up more with the democratic and Christian values of equality and fairness that I believe in.

At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to believe it’s time to move beyond the Electoral College and adopt a national popular vote, so every ballot is counted equally no matter whether you live in Massachusetts or Montana. As a liberal Democrat and a former public school teacher, I care a great deal about fairness and civic education, and it’s hard to explain to young people why the person with fewer votes can still become president. I’d support either abolishing the Electoral College outright or, at the very least, reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact that move us closer to “one person, one vote” in practice, not just in theory.

Given how divided our politics feel, I think it’s time to move away from the Electoral College toward a national popular vote, so that every ballot—whether cast in Kansas or California—counts equally. A system where the presidency goes to the candidate who wins the most votes nationwide would better reflect democratic values, reduce the outsized focus on a handful of swing states, and encourage candidates to speak to the entire country, not just strategic pockets of it.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count the same no matter what state they live in. It doesn’t seem fair that a few swing states get all the attention while a lot of people’s votes basically don’t matter, especially for Black and mixed‑race communities that are sometimes pushed to the side. A popular vote would make politicians focus on everyone, not just certain states.

As someone who deeply values both democracy and good governance, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot, whether cast in California or in a small Midwestern town, counts equally. Coming from Chile and choosing to become a U.S. citizen, it troubles me that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes; that feels inconsistent with the democratic principles I advise organizations to uphold in their own decision-making structures. A reformed system—whether a direct popular vote or a robust interstate compact—would incentivize candidates to speak to all Americans, not just a handful of swing states.

As someone who believes deeply in fairness and individual voice, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. Watching elections come down to a few swing states feels undemocratic and out of step with the country we are now. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and encourage candidates to pay attention to all communities, not just those in battleground states.

Given how much I care about community voices being heard, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. Working in outreach, I see how discouraged people get when they feel their vote is predetermined by “red” or “blue” state math, and that undercuts participation and trust. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and push candidates to engage with all communities, not just a handful of swing states.

As a young dad and a Democrat, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, whether you’re in a swing state or not. Coming from a working-class background, it doesn’t sit right with me that someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, because it makes regular people feel like our voices don’t matter as much. If fully replacing it isn’t politically realistic, I’d support reforms like proportional allocation of electoral votes or the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to make the system more democratic and fair.

As an educator and administrator, I’m troubled that the Electoral College can allow a candidate to win the presidency while losing the national popular vote; that undercuts the civic lesson we try to teach students about every vote counting equally. I would support moving toward a national popular vote—whether through a constitutional amendment or compacts like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact—paired with strong safeguards for election security and equal access to the ballot.

At my age, I’ve lived through enough elections to feel that the Electoral College no longer reflects the will of the people as it should. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, so every ballot counts equally, whether you live in New Jersey or a small rural state, and candidates have to speak to the whole country, not just a few “swing” areas. If that’s too large a leap, at minimum we should require states to allocate electors proportionally, so the outcome more closely matches how citizens actually vote.

At my age, I’ve come to appreciate why the Electoral College was created, and I still think it serves an important purpose in preventing a few big cities from deciding every election. That said, I’d be open to reforms that keep the state-based system but better reflect the people’s will, like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or proportionally instead of winner-take-all. I don’t support scrapping it for a direct popular vote, because that would shift too much power away from states like Virginia and toward large urban centers.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s vote counts equally, no matter what state they live in. It feels unfair that someone could become president without getting the most votes, and that makes people my age feel like the system doesn’t really care about what most of us want.

As a naturalized citizen who chose this country and practices medicine in a diverse hospital, I believe every vote should carry the same weight, regardless of state lines. The Electoral College should be replaced with a direct national popular vote, so that the president is chosen by the clear will of the people, not by an antiquated compromise that can override the majority. Consistent with my humanitarian and Catholic values, a fairer system should amplify each person’s voice equally, especially those in marginalized communities whose needs are too often sidelined.

As someone who believes in broad democratic participation and has seen how diverse and creative communities can be overlooked, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote. Every vote should carry equal weight regardless of where you live, so candidates have to engage with people across the entire country, not just a handful of swing states. If a full replacement isn’t politically feasible right away, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as a major step toward a fairer, more representative system.

Given my background in systems design, I see the Electoral College as an outdated architecture that introduces unnecessary complexity and failure points into our democracy. I favor moving to a national popular vote, supported by modern, auditable election technology and uniform federal standards, so that every vote is weighted equally regardless of state. Short of full abolition, I’d support reforms like proportional allocation of electors and automatic voter registration to reduce distortions while we transition to a fairer, more transparent system.

The Electoral College is an anachronism that ought to be replaced with a national popular vote, so that every citizen’s ballot carries equal weight, whether cast in Minnesota or Mississippi. As someone who spent a lifetime teaching young artists to trust their own voices, I find it deeply troubling that our presidential elections can mute the will of the majority through arcane machinery and “battleground” cartography. If outright abolition proves politically impossible, we should at least adopt reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact and ranked-choice voting, to better reflect the rich, diverse chorus of Americans rather than a handful of swing states.

I think we should get rid of the Electoral College and move to a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter what state they’re in. As someone who works hard in a regular job and sees how diverse people’s lives and views are, it doesn’t sit right that a few swing states decide the outcome while millions of votes elsewhere are basically taken for granted. A popular vote system would push candidates to talk to more kinds of communities, not just the ones that are strategically important.

I don’t support scrapping the Electoral College, because it forces presidential candidates to build broad, nationwide coalitions instead of just chasing votes in a few big cities and coastal states. That said, I’d be open to reforms like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening procedures to make vote counting and certification more transparent and secure.

As a Democrat and someone who believes every person’s voice should count equally, I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a straightforward national popular vote. It doesn’t sit right with me that a candidate can win fewer votes overall but still become president, especially when so many people already feel disconnected from politics. A popular vote would encourage candidates to talk to voters everywhere, not just in a handful of swing states, and that feels more fair and democratic to me.

I think the Electoral College should be reformed so that every person’s vote counts more equally, no matter what state they live in. Maybe we could keep some state role but move toward a national popular vote or a system where electoral votes are awarded proportionally, so candidates have to listen to people in places like where I live, not just the big swing states.

I think the Electoral College should be reformed but not completely scrapped. A system that keeps states relevant, like awarding electoral votes proportionally or by congressional district instead of winner-take-all, would better reflect the popular will without letting only big cities decide everything. As someone raising kids and trying to make ends meet, I want my vote in Oregon to matter more, but I also don’t want rural and smaller states to be ignored.

As an Independent who tries to look at issues from a practical, fair-minded angle, I think the Electoral College should be reformed but not completely abolished. I’d like to see states move toward something like proportional allocation of electoral votes or ranked-choice voting within the current framework, so that every vote feels more meaningful and candidates have to appeal beyond a few swing states. That seems like a reasonable balance between respecting the structure our founders set up and making sure people in all parts of the country, including families like mine, feel their voices count.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime thinking about democracy and policy, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot, whether cast in San Juan or South Dakota, counts equally. The current system sidelines millions of voters—especially in places like Puerto Rico, where we’re U.S. citizens without full voting representation in presidential elections—which undermines both fairness and legitimacy. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people, reduce the outsized power of a few swing states, and bring our elections closer to the democratic ideals we claim to defend around the world.

Given my belief in one-person-one-vote and my experience working in a data-driven, results-oriented industry, I think we should move toward a national popular vote for president or at least significantly reform the Electoral College. It doesn’t make sense that some Americans’ votes effectively count more than others just because of where they live, and that distorts candidates’ incentives, leaving many communities and issues—especially those affecting families like mine—largely ignored. A system that more directly reflects the will of the majority, while still ensuring secure and transparent elections, would better align with both democratic values and basic fairness.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, because it protects the voice of smaller and rural states like West Virginia from being drowned out by big cities and coastal populations. Rather than scrapping it, I’d support modest reforms to increase transparency and ensure electors are bound to the popular vote in their states, so voters can trust that their choices are respected while still maintaining our federalist system.

I don’t think we should scrap the Electoral College, but I do think we can tighten it up so folks trust it more. I’d be open to reforms like making states allocate electors by congressional district or requiring stronger safeguards against fraud, but I’m against a straight national popular vote that would let big coastal cities decide everything. The Electoral College forces candidates to pay attention to different parts of the country, including places like Alabama, and that balance is worth protecting.

As a conservative and a Republican, I think the Electoral College should be preserved because it protects the voice of smaller and less-populated states, preventing our national leadership from being decided solely by a few big coastal cities. I’d support targeted reforms for more transparency and fairness—like standardizing how states allocate their electors or tightening rules around faithless electors—but I don’t want to replace the system with a pure national popular vote that could further polarize the country and ignore places like my home state of Missouri.

Given my background in health care administration, I’m very aware of how systems can become outdated and fail to reflect current realities, and the Electoral College feels like one of those systems. I believe we should move to a national popular vote, or at least adopt reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so every vote truly carries equal weight regardless of state. This would encourage candidates to engage with voters across the entire country, not just in a handful of swing states, and better reflect the diverse voices—including immigrant communities like my own—that make up America.

I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote, or at least significantly reform the Electoral College so every individual vote truly counts the same, no matter what state you live in. As someone who cares about fairness and accountability, I’m uncomfortable with a system where a few swing states effectively decide the outcome and candidates can ignore large parts of the country. A popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and push campaigns to engage with a broader, more diverse set of communities.

Como alguien que no es ciudadana y que viene de México, a veces me cuesta entender por qué el presidente no se elige simplemente por el voto popular, como estoy acostumbrada a pensar. El Colegio Electoral se siente lejano y complicado, y parece que le da más importancia a ciertos estados que a otros. Yo preferiría un sistema donde cada voto cuente igual sin importar en qué estado viva la persona, porque eso me parece más justo y más fácil de confiar.

As a naturalized citizen who came from a country with a more straightforward national vote, I find the Electoral College outdated and at odds with the democratic principle that every vote should count equally. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, or at least reforming it—through measures like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact—to ensure the presidency reflects the will of the majority, not a handful of swing states.

I think the Electoral College is kind of confusing and doesn’t seem fair, because sometimes the person with fewer votes can still become president. It feels like every person’s vote should count the same, no matter what state they live in, so I’d rather have a system where the winner is just whoever gets the most votes in the whole country.

As a civics-minded teacher and a mom, I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether you live in Utah or New York. The current system teaches my students that some states matter more than others, which cuts against the democratic values and fairness I’m trying to instill in them. If a full replacement isn’t politically realistic right now, I’d strongly support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as a practical step toward “one person, one vote” in presidential elections.

As a naturalized citizen who worked hard to build a life here, it bothers me that the Electoral College can effectively make some people’s votes count more than others, especially in states with large Black and immigrant communities that are taken for granted. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, or at least proportional allocation of electoral votes within each state, so every ballot genuinely matters. A system that reflects the actual will of the majority would better align with my democratic and Jewish values of fairness, dignity, and shared responsibility.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose by making sure smaller and rural states like mine aren’t completely drowned out by big coastal cities, so I wouldn’t get rid of it. That said, I’d be open to modest reforms—like standardizing how states allocate their electors or improving transparency—so people feel their votes are counted fairly, without turning the whole system into a straight national popular vote.

My mommy and daddy tell me that everyone’s vote should matter the same, no matter where they live, because God loves all people equally. I think it would be better if the president was picked by whoever gets the most votes from all the people put together, so no one feels left out or like their voice doesn’t count.

I don’t totally get how the Electoral College works, but I think it would be fair if everyone’s vote counted the same, no matter what state they live in. Grown-ups should make sure that when people vote for president, the person who gets the most votes from everyone in the whole country wins, like when you count all the points in a game to see who really won.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but cleaned up, not scrapped. It forces candidates to pay attention to different parts of the country instead of just big cities, which protects smaller and more rural states like mine. That said, I’d support reforms that make the rules more consistent across states and tighten up how votes are counted so people can trust the outcome.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but it could use some tightening up around things like how electors are chosen and making sure states follow clear, consistent rules. As someone who believes in the Constitution and in the importance of states having a real voice, I worry that going to a straight national popular vote would let big coastal cities drown out places like Indiana. That said, I’d support reforms that increase transparency and prevent any attempt to game the system, as long as we preserve the basic structure that balances power between the states.

As someone who works hard every day and is raising kids on my own, I don’t like the idea that my vote can count less just because of where I live, so I’d support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote. The president should be the person who gets the most votes from the people, period, and everyone’s ballot—from a school janitor in New York to a farmer in the Midwest—should matter equally.

I don’t know all the details of how the Electoral College works, but it seems kind of unfair that someone can win the popular vote and still lose the election. I think we should move closer to a system where every person’s vote counts equally, maybe by using the national popular vote or splitting electoral votes by district instead of winner-take-all in each state.

I don’t totally get all the big rules about the Electoral College, but I think it would be fairer if every person’s vote counted the same, no matter what state they live in. Maybe we could change it so that whoever gets the most votes in the whole country becomes president, kind of like how in school elections the kid with the most votes wins.

As a progressive Democrat who believes in every voice counting equally, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so the presidency goes to whoever wins the most votes, plain and simple. Coming from Texas and seeing how many votes feel “wasted” in a safe state, I want a system where candidates have to talk to voters everywhere, not just in a handful of swing states. A direct popular vote would better reflect the diversity of our country—including people like me from Mexican backgrounds—and strengthen faith in our democracy.

As someone who became a citizen by choice and believes deeply in civic participation, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot is counted equally, no matter what state you live in. Working closely with people in their homes, I see how many feel ignored because they’re not in a “battleground” state, and that undermines faith in democracy. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people, encourage higher turnout, and align with the values of fairness and equal voice that drew me to the U.S. in the first place.

As someone who travels and performs across the country, I’m constantly reminded that every voice deserves the same weight, whether it’s in New York or a small town in the Midwest. I’d support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote, or at least adopting reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so the presidency truly reflects the will of the majority. A system where some states are “battlegrounds” and others are background noise doesn’t reflect the democratic, expressive spirit I believe art—and our politics—should embody.

I think we should keep the Electoral College, but maybe update it a bit so that each state’s votes are harder to “cancel out” by just a few big cities. Out here, folks like me feel our voices already get ignored enough, and a pure popular vote would make candidates focus only on the coasts and huge urban areas. If there are reforms, they should make sure smaller states and rural communities still matter, while increasing transparency so people trust the process more.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every vote really counts the same, no matter what state you live in. A national popular vote sounds fairer, because then the person who gets the most votes actually wins, and candidates would have to care about people in every state, not just the swing states.

As someone who believes in democracy and comes from a community that’s seen its voice diluted before, I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system makes a few swing states way too powerful, and that doesn’t sit right with my values of fairness and representation. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to all kinds of communities—urban, rural, Black, white, and everything in between—instead of just chasing electoral math.

At my age, having watched so many elections come and go, I’ve grown convinced the Electoral College no longer reflects the will of the people the way a modern democracy should. I would prefer a national popular vote, or at least reforms like ranked-choice voting within states, so every ballot counts equally no matter where you live. As a retired teacher and lifelong Democrat, I believe simplifying the system and making it more transparent would help younger generations trust that their participation truly matters.

As someone who believes in our constitutional framework and the balance between large and small states, I think we should keep the Electoral College but modernize it rather than scrap it. Reforms like allocating electors proportionally by congressional district, tightening rules on “faithless electors,” and improving transparency in how votes are counted would respect the voice of the states while making the system feel fairer and more representative.

As someone who believes in environmental protection and supports the Green Party, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you’re in. Right now, candidates basically ignore states they see as “safe” or “unwinnable,” which shuts out a lot of voices and makes it harder for smaller parties and climate-focused platforms to get real traction. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to everyone, including young working people like me, instead of just chasing swing states.

Como ciudadana naturalizada y demócrata que cree en la igualdad social, pienso que el Colegio Electoral ya no representa bien la voluntad del pueblo. Me gustaría ver una reforma que avance hacia la elección directa por voto popular nacional, o al menos un sistema proporcional por estados, para que cada voto cuente igual sin importar dónde viva la persona. Como alguien que llegó de Cuba buscando una democracia más justa, me preocupa que un candidato pueda ganar la presidencia perdiendo el voto popular, porque eso debilita la confianza en el sistema.

I think it’s past time we moved to a national popular vote so every ballot counts the same, whether you’re in a swing state or not. As a small business owner and a Black woman, I’m tired of seeing candidates chase after a handful of states while ignoring communities like mine that always show up to vote. We need a system where the person with the most votes actually wins, and where turnout in places like rural Virginia matters just as much as it does in Ohio or Florida.

As someone who works long hours and is raising kids on my own, I feel like every vote should count the same, no matter what state you live in. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so candidates have to speak to all Americans, not just a handful of swing states, and so people in places like Michigan don’t feel sidelined. That seems more fair, more democratic, and more in line with the idea that we’re all equal citizens.

As someone who believes in our Constitution and the balance between states and the federal government, I think the Electoral College should be kept, but it could be improved. I’d support reforms like requiring states to allocate electoral votes by congressional district or proportionally, so people in the minority party in each state still have their voices heard. That way, we protect the voice of smaller states like Alabama while making the system feel fairer to more Americans.

As an old engineer, I tend to like systems that are simple, transparent, and robust, and the Electoral College doesn’t really fit that bill anymore. I’d support moving to a national popular vote with some safeguards—like nonpartisan election administration and strong verification—so every vote counts the same no matter where you live, including rural folks like many I grew up with in Minnesota. At the very least, we should reform the Electoral College by eliminating winner‑take‑all at the state level—maybe using proportional allocation—so that people aren’t effectively silenced just because they live in a “safe” state.

As a naturalized citizen and a mom, I want my vote—and my daughter’s future vote—to matter just as much as anyone’s, no matter what state we live in. At my age, I’ve seen the Electoral College protect smaller and rural states from being completely ignored by big coastal cities, and I still think that balance matters. I’d keep the Electoral College, but I’d like to see reforms such as states adopting proportional allocation of electoral votes instead of winner-take-all, so people in the minority party in each state still feel their votes count. That way we preserve the voice of diverse regions while making the system fairer and more responsive to the popular will.

I think it’s time we moved to a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts the same, no matter where they live. As someone who believes in community and fairness, it bothers me that a few swing states get all the attention while the rest of us are basically taken for granted. A system where the candidate with the most votes simply wins would feel more democratic and might encourage more people to stay engaged and believe their voices matter.

As someone who became a citizen by choice and cares deeply about democratic participation, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, no matter the state. The current system distorts campaigns around a few swing states and discourages turnout in places seen as safely red or blue, which undercuts the principle of one person, one vote. A direct popular vote, with strong protections for voting rights and access, would better reflect the will of the people and strengthen faith in our democracy.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved because it protects the voice of smaller and more rural states like Indiana, so that big coastal cities don’t decide every election on their own. If there are reforms, they should focus on improving transparency and integrity in how electors are chosen and votes are counted, not on eliminating a system that helps keep our republic balanced and accountable.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that the popular vote matters more, because it feels unfair that some people’s votes count more just because of where they live. As someone who’s still too young to vote but cares about fairness and everyone having an equal voice, I’d like a system where every person’s vote is weighed the same, no matter the state.

At my age, I’ve seen this country go through many changes, and I believe our Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller and more rural states from being drowned out by big cities. I don’t support abolishing it, but I would be open to some modest reforms—like making sure states run their elections more uniformly and transparently—so people can trust the results. The Founders designed a system to slow down sudden swings in public opinion, and I think that stability has been good for America.

As a Catholic and a Democrat who cares deeply about fairness and the common good, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter where they live. Right now, candidates focus on a handful of swing states and ignore so many voices, which doesn’t sit right with my sense of justice or my belief in the dignity of every person. I’d support reforms that either abolish the Electoral College or bind it more tightly to the national popular vote, so the winner truly reflects the will of the majority.

At this stage in my life, looking back on decades of teaching and studying institutions, I’ve come to see the Electoral College as an anachronism that too often distorts the popular will and encourages candidates to fixate on a handful of swing states. I would favor moving to a national popular vote for president, ideally with ranked-choice voting, so that every ballot carries equal weight and citizens are encouraged to vote their true preferences without worrying about “wasting” their vote.

I think the Electoral College should be kept mostly as it is, because it forces candidates to pay attention to smaller and rural states like Iowa instead of just chasing votes in big cities and the coasts. If there’s any reform, I’d support tightening up the rules around how states run their elections and count their votes so people can trust the results, but I don’t want a straight popular vote that would drown out folks in places like my town.

I think the Electoral College could use a tune‑up, not a full engine swap. I’d keep the state-by-state system, but move to something like Maine and Nebraska where electoral votes are split by congressional district, so folks like me in smaller or less flashy states don’t get totally drowned out. A straight popular vote sounds fair on paper, but I don’t trust putting all the power in big cities and national media bubbles. We need a system that keeps candidates from ignoring the “back roads” parts of America while still better reflecting how people actually vote.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, because it protects the voice of smaller and less populated states so that our elections aren’t decided only by a handful of big cities. If anything, reforms should focus on improving transparency and security in how states run their elections and allocate their electors, not on replacing the system altogether.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every person’s vote counts equally, no matter what state they live in, maybe by using a national popular vote instead. It doesn’t feel fair that someone in a “swing state” has more influence than someone in a state that usually votes the same way, because we’re all supposed to be equal in a democracy.

I don’t really understand big voting rules yet, but I know it’s important that everyone feels like their voice matters and that things are fair. If grown‑ups changed the Electoral College, I’d want them to make it so every person’s vote counts the same no matter where they live, because my teachers say fairness is important and that everyone should be included.

As a teacher and a progressive Democrat, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every citizen’s ballot carries equal weight, no matter what state they live in. I see firsthand how young people become cynical when they realize some votes effectively matter more than others, and that contradicts the basic civics lessons I teach about fairness and democracy. At the very least, we should move toward reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact and nonpartisan election administration to ensure the outcome truly reflects the will of the majority.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so every person’s ballot counts the same no matter what state they live in. It feels wrong that someone can win the presidency without winning the most votes, and as a Democrat and a liberal, I care a lot about making our system more directly democratic. If a full popular vote isn’t possible right away, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to move us closer to one-person, one-vote in practice.

Coming from a rural, conservative background, I actually support keeping the Electoral College but think some tweaks could make it fairer. It protects smaller and more rural states like mine from being totally ignored by big cities, which matters for people who work the land and feed the country. That said, I’d be open to reforms like allocating electors by congressional district instead of winner‑take‑all in each state, so people’s votes are better reflected without wiping out the voice of less populated areas.

As a conservative Christian and a mom, I see the value in the Electoral College because it protects smaller and less-populated states like Tennessee from being ignored by big coastal cities. That said, I’d support modest reforms—such as more transparency in how electors are chosen or requiring them to follow the state’s popular vote—to strengthen trust in elections without tearing down a system that helps preserve our federal balance and encourages candidates to campaign across the whole country, not just in a few large population centers.

The Electoral College needs serious reform, if not outright replacement, because it lets a handful of swing states decide elections instead of treating every citizen’s vote equally. I’d support a national popular vote with strong safeguards for election integrity, federalism, and ballot access, so smaller states and minority viewpoints aren’t steamrolled by big-city majorities. A system like ranked-choice voting at the national level could also open the door for viable independent and third-party candidates, which fits my belief in individual choice over rigid party machines. Whatever we do, it should increase accountability to actual voters, not to party strategists gaming the map.

As a Democrat who believes in fairness and everyone’s voice counting equally, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that the candidate with the most votes actually wins. Working in a residential care facility and seeing how ordinary people often feel ignored, it seems wrong that some voters in swing states matter more than others just because of where they live. A direct popular vote would make every ballot, whether it’s cast in Nebraska or New York, count the same and encourage candidates to pay attention to all Americans, not just a handful of states.

As a conservative and a veteran, I think the Electoral College should be preserved because it forces candidates to pay attention to a broad range of states, not just the biggest cities and population centers. That said, I’d support reforms that increase transparency and standardize election procedures across states, as long as they don’t undermine the balance between large and small states.

As someone who has spent a lifetime studying how ancient societies organized power and legitimacy, I find the Electoral College to be an outdated compromise that no longer reflects a truly representative democracy. I would favor replacing it with a national popular vote, or at minimum adopting reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so that every citizen’s ballot counts equally regardless of state lines. The current system distorts campaigning toward a handful of swing states and, on occasion, produces presidents who did not win the popular vote—outcomes that undermine both democratic fairness and public trust.
